title: Update dev deps
feat: Allow toString to stringify JSON Objects
body:
Old behaviour:

```js
> _.toString({a: 'b'})
"[object Object]"
```

New behaviour:

```js
> _.toString({a: 'b'})
"{"a":"b"}"
```

title: Are the docs incorrect for sortBy?
body:
[The docs](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#sortBy) show the sortBy arguments as being:


> **Arguments**
>
>  `collection (Array|Object)`: The collection to iterate over.
>
>  `[iteratees=[_.identity]] (...(Function|Function[]))`: The iteratees to sort by.

Whereas in Lodash 3, the iteratee [was shown](https://lodash.com/docs/3.10.1#sortBy) as:

> `[iteratee=_.identity] (Function|Object|string)`: The function invoked per iteration.

..with a note that:
> If a property name is provided for iteratee the created _.property style callback returns the property value of the given element.

But it seems that `string` still works.  In fact the Lodash 4 example shows:
```ts
var users = [
  { 'user': 'fred',   'age': 48 },
  { 'user': 'barney', 'age': 36 },
  { 'user': 'fred',   'age': 40 },
  { 'user': 'barney', 'age': 34 }
];
_.sortBy(users, ['user', 'age']);
// => objects for [['barney', 34], ['barney', 36], ['fred', 40], ['fred', 48]]
```
...and it does seem to sort by the named properties.

Does Lodash 4 officially support a property name string as the iteratee?  If so, why don't the Lodash 4 docs list it as `[iteratee=_.identity] (Function|Object|string)`?  In other words, if the behavior hasn't changed since Lodash 3, then why were the docs changed?

title: Documentation for functions supporting iteratee shorthand seems incorrect
body:
Background: I've been trying to do some cleanup on our codebase and the inspection tool started telling me a variety of lodash functions were being used incorrectly.

Things like:  `_.uniqBy(someArray, 'someKey')` was incorrectly being used because 'someKey' isn't a function. The JSDoc for _.uniqBy that I have currently:
```javascript
/**
 * This method is like `_.uniq` except that it accepts `iteratee` which is
 * invoked for each element in `array` to generate the criterion by which
 * uniqueness is computed. The order of result values is determined by the
 * order they occur in the array. The iteratee is invoked with one argument:
 * (value).
 *
 * @static
 * @memberOf _
 * @since 4.0.0
 * @category Array
 * @param {Array} array The array to inspect.
 * @param {Function} [iteratee=_.identity] The iteratee invoked per element.
 * @returns {Array} Returns the new duplicate free array.
 * @example
 *
 * _.uniqBy([2.1, 1.2, 2.3], Math.floor);
 * // => [2.1, 1.2]
 *
 * // The `_.property` iteratee shorthand.
 * _.uniqBy([{ 'x': 1 }, { 'x': 2 }, { 'x': 1 }], 'x');
 * // => [{ 'x': 1 }, { 'x': 2 }]
 */
```
 Quite a few other functions that use some form of "shorthand" end up giving the same kind of error.

I'm not sure if this was intentional or not but it does make my inspection tool tell me a lot of false-positives when coding using lodash and its shorthands.

Is there a way to improve the documentation that would alleviate this or is it just a known pain point?

title: :bug defaultValue when the get parameter is null

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
### Problem
When the parameter of the get method is null, the defaultValue setting is not entered.
This is not the normal process we expect

E.g
```
import { get } from 'lodash'

const params = {
  a: null
}

get(params, 'a', 'defaultValue')   // return null

```

title: Omission of certain functions for version 5.0.0

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Having gone through the roadmap for version 5.0.0, it is a pity that some functions will be omitted. The native implementation in JS are not as strong as the ones in `lodash` with regards to null-safety or currying capability for functional patterns.
Additionally, at least for the functional approach, it would make sense to keep functions like `curry`, `spread` and others for function composition patterns.

Certainly we could attempt to create our own functions but I reckon that the reason why many use `lodash` is that we don't want to reinvent the wheel when it is already somewhere implemented and well tested.

title: _.isEqual(NaN, NaN) returns true
body: In JavaScript, NaN has the distinction of being the only value that is not equal to itself. We can add this functionality to isEqual function by using ES6 Number.isNaN function to check if the parameters are NaN or not.

title: Add `_.getWith`
Did/Does lodash secretly have dependencies?
body:
It is my understanding that lodash has 0 dependencies.

But I am wondering if other libraries are/were "secretly" rolled in at some point.

The reason I am wondering this is because we are using an old `lodash` bower component in a project.  lodash is installed in `node_modules/@bower_components/lodash`.  That folder contains a file called `yarn.lock` (and also `package-lock.json`).  Inside the file, certain dependency information is listed.  For example:

    deep-extend@~0.4.0:
      version "0.4.1"
      resolved "https://registry.yarnpkg.com/deep-extend/-/deep-extend-0.4.1.tgz#efe4113d08085f4e6f9687759810f807469e2253"

Does this mean that lodash depends on deep-extend?  Or perhaps it means just the opposite, that deep-extend depends on lodash.

Thanks in advance for clarifying what this information really means.

For example, I'm building an application that will allow developers to automatically donate ETH to all of their npm dependencies that have Ethereum addresses in their package.json files: https://sustainus.io

title: propertyOf (lodash/fp): Rearranged Arguments
body:
The [documentation](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/FP-Guide#exceptions-to-the-rules) for lodash/fp's `propertyOf` states that the method does not have its arguments rearranged. However, the method accepts the `path` argument before the `collection` argument, which is different than the argument order of `propertyOf` from the standard lodash library.

To fix, we could switch the order of accepted arguments for `propertyOf`. Or, if this behavior is intended, we could update the documentation.

title: discourage people from using per-method packages on website?
body:
As far as I understand in #3838, there aren't really any great reasons to use per-method packages.  I've still seen a number of libs in the wild that use them, thinking it will reduce their dependency footprint.  They don't realize it will ultimately end up bloating dependencies and webpack bundles since the per-method packages can't share as much code with other libs that depend on lodash methods.

I propose we make the `per-method packages` link on the webpage go to a warning page that explains why people should stop using the per-method packages, before showing them the link to all the per-method packages on npm.

title: cloneWith unexpected behaviour
body:
https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#cloneWith

> This method is like _.clone except that it accepts **customizer which is invoked to produce the cloned value.**

```
_.cloneWith({ foo: 3, bar: 4 }, () => 'value')
```

returns

```
'value'
```

expected

```
{ foo: 'value', bar: 'value' }
```

or am I misunderstanding `cloneWith`?

title: pipeline utility function proposal (for those who don't want to choose between the 3 pipeline operator proposals)
body:
I'm excited about the pipeline operator proposal, but my boss and I agreed we'd rather not start using it since there are 3 competing implementations...

Using `flow` is a pretty suitable alternative, but awkward in that the input value comes last:
```js
flow(
  compact,
  map(x => x * 2)
)([1, 2, null, 3])
// [2, 4, 6]
```
With this simple declaration, we can get the same ordering as the pipeline operator:

```js
const pipeline = (value, ...fns) => flow(...fns)(value)

pipeline(
  [1, 2, null, 3],
  compact,
  map(x => x * 2)
)
// [2, 4, 6]
```

Do you think this `pipeline` function is worthy of being part of Lodash?  Would be nice not to have to define it separately in each of our project.

There doesn't seem to be an easily-discoverable package exporting this function on npm...

title: Question - using _.cloneDeep with cyclic graph objects
body:
Project consists of cyclic graph objects. We use JSOG library to stringify the cyclic graph. With v3.10.1 using _.cloneDeep and stringify worked like a charm. However, after upgrading to v4.17.15, we have an issue with it. 

Uncaught TypeError: Converting circular structure to JSON
    --> starting at object with constructor 'Object'
    |     property 'person' -> object with constructor 'Object'
    |     property 'organization' -> object with constructor 'Array'
    --- index 0 closes the circle
    at JSON.stringify (<anonymous>)

Any suggestion how we can somehow continue using _.cloneDeep (or is there anything else that can be used)  ? Thanks in advance.

title: Error when using _.isTypedArray on ie11
Lodash support for Json pointer
body:
Would be great for lodash to support json pointers as defined in [RFC 6901](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901), so for example given a JSON:

```
object = {
    "foo" : ["bar", "baz"],
    "pi" : 3.1416
}
```

The following JSON Pointers resolve this JSON as:

```
"/foo" → [ "bar", "baz" ]
"/foo/0" → "bar"
"/foo/1" → "baz"
"/pi" → 3.1416
```

so 
```
_.get(object, "/foo") = [ "bar", "baz" ]
_.get(object, "/foo/0") = "bar"
_.get(object, "/foo/1") = "baz"
_.get(object, "/pi") = 3.1416
```

title: Debounced async function returns no promise
body:
Hi There,

node: `v10.16.0`
lodash: `^4.17.15`

Using `_.debounce` with a function that returns a promise does not return a promise on the first call. For example:

```js
const debounce = require('lodash/debounce')

const test = async () => 7

const debounced = debounce(test, 1000)

const calls = []

calls.push(debounced())
setTimeout(() => { calls.push(debounced()) }, 1500)
setTimeout(() => { calls.push(debounced()) && console.dir(calls) }, 3000)

// Output: [ undefined, Promise { 7 }, Promise { 7 } ]
```

I expect all calls to be promises. Am I mistaken?

**Edit:**
Changed example to better demonstrate issue

title: Vote for locked issue?
body:
I would like to vote for https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/2169, but I cannot add a reaction to a locked issue? It seems counter-intuitive to gauge interest in features by reactions but then prevent people for adding them. Is this intentional or an unintended side affect?

Thanks!

title: Internal usage of the `Date` class
body:
There seems to be a discrepancy in internal implementations regarding their usage of the `Date` class, especially the `now` function.

The `now` lodash method uses the lodash `root` object representing the global context to get the `Date` class whose `now` method should be called.

On the contrary, `_shortOut.js` contains the following binding:

    var nativeNow = Date.now;

I personally would have expected, that `nativeNow` would also make use of lodash's `root` object.

Actually, with the current state of the implementation and the absence of specific documentation comments, this difference makes me doubt the correctness of both the implementation of the `now` function and the `shortOut` function.

title: Ability to pass a method with arguments as an iteratie
body:
As far as I understand, only a method with one argument can be an iteratee except the `property` and `matches` iteratee.

I think it would be useful to allow any function to be an iteratee with a syntax like:

```
a = [{a: 1, b: 2}, {a: 3, c:4}]
_.map(a, _.iteratee('pick', ['a'])) // => [{a:1}, {a:3}]
_.map(a, _.iteratee('update', 'b', null)) // => [{a: 1, b: null}, {a: 3, b: null, c: 4}]
```

Alternate syntax:

```
_.iteratees.update('b', null)
_.update.iteratee('b', null)
```

title: Why is there no functionality to work with siblings?
[ question ]why get length of array in this way?
body:
`const { length } = array`
what's the difference between 
`const length = array.length`
?
is it faster? just curious

And why create an Array in this way?
```
const result = new array.constructor(length)
```
🧐

title: memoize: a way to preserve name of function?
body:
there doesn't seem to be a way to get the name of the original function after it's been memoized.  should there be?

maybe store the original name on the function:
```js
const myFun = () => "hello lodash"
const memoizedMyFun = _.memoize(myFun)
console.log(memoizedMyFun.originalName) // myFun
```

better for logging and debugging
